verses.text: When Israel went out from Egypt, the house of Jacob from a people of strange language,
verses.comment: This opening verse recalls the Exodus, a foundational event in the faith. The phrase 'a people of strange language' emphasizes Israel's distinctness and God's call to bring them out from foreign oppression. See Isaiah 28:11 for a spiritual application of foreign tongues.

verses.text: Judah became his sanctuary, Israel his dominion.
verses.comment: A reference to the unique status of Judah and Israel as God’s holy people and chosen domain. Note the sacramental undertone: God sets apart a people and a place for his dwelling. Cf. Gen. 28:17.

verses.text: The sea looked and fled; the Jordan turned back.
verses.comment: This recounts the miracles at the Red Sea and the Jordan River, where waters parted before God's people. This is both literal history and a foreshadowing of spiritual cleansing and new beginnings, as fulfilled in Christian baptism. See also 1 Cor. 10:1-2.

verses.text: The mountains skipped like rams, the hills like lambs.
verses.comment: A poetic description of the earth responding to God's presence. The figurative language expresses creation’s awe and submission. Compare with Jude 1:5 who links these events to the Lord’s authority.

verses.text: Why is it, O sea, that you flee? O Jordan, that you turn back?
verses.comment: A rhetorical question, pointing to God’s overwhelming power over nature. This invites the reader to reflect on divine intervention as an ongoing reality—God acts decisively for his people.

verses.text: O mountains, that you skip like rams? O hills, like lambs?
verses.comment: Another repetition for poetic emphasis, highlighting creation’s obedience to its Creator. Spiritual interpretation: all creation moves in response to the presence of the Lord (see Rom. 8:19-22).

verses.text: Tremble, O earth, at the presence of the Lord, at the presence of the God of Jacob,
verses.comment: The earth shudders before God’s manifest presence. This reveals both God’s majesty and his closeness to his people. The phrase 'the Lord' is a title for God’s unique personal identity, anticipating the ultimate revelation in the Incarnation.

verses.text: who turns the rock into a pool of water, the flint into a spring of water.
verses.comment: God provides water from the rock, sustaining his people. This miracle prefigures the spiritual sustenance given through Christ, whom the Apostle Paul calls 'the Rock.' See 1 Cor. 10:4. The church has always seen this as a type of spiritual nourishment—bread and living water—offered continually to God’s people.
